validated_facts.section: Difference in Treatment Outcome in Outpatients With Anxious Versus Nonanxious Depression: A STAR*D Report
validated_facts.span: A total of 2,876 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder, enrolled from 18 primary and 23 psychiatric care sites, received citalopram in Level 1 of STAR*D. Treatment could last up to 14 weeks in each level.

validated_facts.section: Difference in Treatment Outcome in Outpatients With Anxious Versus Nonanxious Depression: A STAR*D Report
validated_facts.span: In Level 2, a total of 1,292 patients who did not remit with or tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned either to switch to sustained-release bupropion (N=239), sertraline (N=238), or extended-release venlafaxine (N=250) or to continue taking citalopram and receive augmentation with sustained-release bupropion (N=279) or buspirone (N=286). Treatment could last up to 14 weeks in each level.

validated_facts.section: Difference in Treatment Outcome in Outpatients With Anxious Versus Nonanxious Depression: A STAR*D Report
validated_facts.span: In Level 2, a total of 1,292 patients who did not remit with or tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned either to switch to sustained-release bupropion (N=239), sertraline (N=238), or extended-release venlafaxine (N=250) or to continue taking citalopram and receive augmentation with sustained-release bupropion (N=279) or buspirone (N=286). Treatment could last up to 14 weeks in each level.

validated_facts.section: Difference in Treatment Outcome in Outpatients With Anxious Versus Nonanxious Depression: A STAR*D Report
validated_facts.span: In Level 2, a total of 1,292 patients who did not remit with or tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned either to switch to sustained-release bupropion (N=239), sertraline (N=238), or extended-release venlafaxine (N=250) or to continue taking citalopram and receive augmentation with sustained-release bupropion (N=279) or buspirone (N=286). Treatment could last up to 14 weeks in each level.

validated_facts.section: Difference in Treatment Outcome in Outpatients With Anxious Versus Nonanxious Depression: A STAR*D Report
validated_facts.span: In Level 2, a total of 1,292 patients who did not remit with or tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned either to switch to sustained-release bupropion (N=239), sertraline (N=238), or extended-release venlafaxine (N=250) or to continue taking citalopram and receive augmentation with sustained-release bupropion (N=279) or buspirone (N=286). Treatment could last up to 14 weeks in each level.

The aim of citalopram treatment in Level 1 was to achieve symptom remission, which was defined as QIDS-C score â‰¤ 5. The protocol required a fully adequate dose of citalopram for a sufficient time to maximize the likelihood of achieving remission.

side_effects: greater frequency, intensity, and burden of side effects
validated_facts.section: Tolerability and Side Effects in Level 1, by Anxious Versus Nonanxious Depression
validated_facts.span: Despite similar citalopram dosages in the two groups and the longer treatment exposure in the nonanxious depression group (Table 1), the anxious depression group had greater a frequency, intensity, and burden of side effects than the nonanxious depression group, as well as more serious adverse events (Table 4).

validated_facts.section: Tolerability and Side Effects in Level 1, by Anxious Versus Nonanxious Depression
validated_facts.span: Despite similar citalopram dosages in the two groups and the longer treatment exposure in the nonanxious depression group (Table 1), the anxious depression group had greater a frequency, intensity, and burden of side effects than the nonanxious depression group, as well as more serious adverse events (Table 4).

validated_facts.section: Sample Description of Level 2 Study Participants
validated_facts.span: In Level 2 of STAR*D, 1,292 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder who had no remission of symptoms in Level 1 or could not tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned to continue taking citalopram and receive augmentation with sustained-release bupropion (at a dose of up to 400 mg per day; N=279).

validated_facts.section: Sample Description of Level 2 Study Participants
validated_facts.span: In Level 2 of STAR*D, 1,292 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder who had no remission of symptoms in Level 1 or could not tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned to continue taking citalopram and receive augmentation with buspirone (at a dose of up to 60 mg per day; N=286).

validated_facts.section: Sample Description of Level 2 Study Participants
validated_facts.span: In Level 2 of STAR*D, 1,292 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder who had no remission of symptoms in Level 1 or could not tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned to switch to sustained-release bupropion (at a maximal daily dose of 400 mg; N=239).

validated_facts.section: Sample Description of Level 2 Study Participants
validated_facts.span: In Level 2 of STAR*D, 1,292 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder who had no remission of symptoms in Level 1 or could not tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned to switch to sertraline (at a maximal daily dose of 200 mg; N=238).

validated_facts.section: Sample Description of Level 2 Study Participants
validated_facts.span: In Level 2 of STAR*D, 1,292 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder who had no remission of symptoms in Level 1 or could not tolerate citalopram were randomly assigned to switch to extended-release venlafaxine (at a maximal daily dose of 375 mg; N=250).

In Level 1 of STAR*D, patients with anxious depression were less likely to respond or to remit with citalopram treatment than those with nonanxious depression. Overall, they also took longer to remit.

After 6 weeks of combined treatment with citalopram and a benzodiazepine, Ms. D reported a significant improvement in all her symptoms, and remission was achieved at the end of the 10th week of treatment.
A benzodiazepine was prescribed, which brought about a significant improvement in her insomnia and agitation.
